com.apriori.graph

Class Graph<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.apriori.graph.Graph<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T - the type of value produced by the computation graph

    public class Graph<T>
extends java.lang.Object
    A computation graph. Each node in a computation graph represents an operation. The way nodes are connected implicitly constrains parallelism. Computing the result of a graph will run the node operations in parallel where it can, queuing up operations as their inputs are computed.

    Computation graphs are static. Once the graph is created, the nodes are fixed. So calculations cannot change edges or create/remove nodes conditionally during execution. To execute graphs where steps are conditional, you could check the condition in a node and just immediately return a sentinel value if the node is not actually needed. Dependent node operations can look for the sentinel value to decide if that value is available, or they can just re-check the condition to see if they even want to examine the input.

    Defining the graph is done by defining the nodes and edges.

    See Also:
    Node.toGraph()

    • Method Detail

      • inputKeys

        public java.util.Set<Key<?>> inputKeys()
        The input keys that must be bound to the graph in order to compute it. This set is computed by looking at all nodes in the graph and finding all of the distinct input keys.
        Returns:
        the set of input keys that must be bound in order to compute the graph

      • resultNode

        public Node<T> resultNode()
        The node in the graph that supplies the final product of the graph.
        Returns:
        the graph node that supplies the graph's result

      • newComputation

        public Graph.Computation<T> newComputation()
        Creates a new computation for this graph. The graph represents the computation's structure. An individual computation is an object that can be invoked and produce a value.
        Returns:
        a new computation for this graph

      • newComputation

        public Graph.Computation<T> newComputation(java.util.concurrent.Executor e)
        Creates a new computation for this graph that uses the given executor to execute node operations.

        Note: Using constrained parallelism with nodes that have async inputs can cause the computation to deadlock.

        Parameters:
        e - an executor
        Returns:
        a new computation for this graph
        See Also:
        withDefaultExecutor(Executor)

      • withDefaultExecutor

        public Graph<T> withDefaultExecutor(java.util.concurrent.Executor e)
        Creates a copy of this graph that uses a different default executor for new computations. This is for computations that are created without specifying an executor to use.

        Note: Using constrained parallelism with nodes that have async inputs can cause the computation to deadlock.

        This can happen because nodes with async inputs are allowed to start before all of their dependencies are complete. If such nodes get queued before their async dependencies, they could block all threads of execution, waiting on dependencies to complete. If this happens, the computation has deadlocked and won't finish.

        For this reason, the default executor (when not overridden with this method) does not constrain parallelism.

        Parameters:
        e - the executor to use as the default executor for new computations
        Returns:
        a new graph that uses the given executor as its default
